subject: Re: [junit] chosing between jmock and easymock for mocks?

messageBody:
First to the starter of this thread, check this framework out aswell:
rmock.sf.net it is comparable to EasyMock but is nicer in some ways I
think (it does not have the cool 1.5 stuff that EasyMock does though).
I'll talk more about it below :)

To Joe,

I have a lot of respect for you and your opinions and I usually enjoy
your posts and agree with what you write but did you really think this
one through: (?)

> First, I don't know why he's creating a constant for every method he
> mocks. If he lives in a world where all literals must be stored in a
> constant, that's not jMock's fault. That's called "tyranny" and is bound
> to bad for a number of other reasons.

About keeping all literals constants I coudn't agree more. But if you
need to use the same method over and over again it kind of bites when
you need to change it doesn't it? So in a way you could say jMock
forces you to do that (or search replace, or not change that many
methods that often, or be really clever when you write your tests).

I think jMock tend to bite beginners a bit more than record/replay
frameworks such as easyMock. If you are really good at test-driven
programming, understand interaction based testing fully and know all
your patterns and your OO-principles you will not have a big problem
with jMock, Your test will not have that much setUp-code that the
"declarative" nature is a problem.

However in most projects (if not all) I have been on there have been a
few people that are not (yet) that great at TDD or OO for that matter.
Very few have yet seen the light when it comes to interaction based
testing and think that it is used primarily for isolating your system
from external systems. With that view they will use any mock-framework
poorly. They make mistakes and learn from them same as we all have
done. There will be tests with too complicated setup etc, they might
not be your's but you may have to change them when refactoring
something else...

> Still, there's a flipside to the whole "can't generate a method stub"
> argument. With EasyMock, if I use a faked or mocked method that doesn't
> yet exist, my test can't even compile yet!

Yes but I see that as a good thing, I totally don't see the problem.
You will have compilation errors if your compiler runs automatically
like in eclipse but that is kind of because it doesn't compile right?

> When I practise TDD, I often
> design interfaces, and forcing me to generate a method stub for a method
> I might not even like yet is annoying.

I usually create my interfaces from tests too and I think if anything
RMock and Easymock promtes that: ctrl-space, done. If you don't like
the method at some later Ã¶point, delete. I don't see how this can be
annoying. You allways have the oportunity not to generate the method
if you until you like it and whith rMock and EasyMock you can
automatically refactor it to something you like when you know what you
like, with jmock this is a bit harder IMHO. _I_ personally find it way
more annying to replace all occurences of a method that I decided I
didn't like at some point later when I know more about the system I'm
coding than I did when I created an interface.

> Keeping the methods as strings
> allows me to write the test, compile it, and even run it before I decide
> whether the interface or method signature is good enough to start
> putting into stone.

What does putting it into stone mean? It is not like you cannot change
your mind once you generated your method-stub and it is not like you
can't refactor it later (unless you're using jMock :))

And what is the point in running it, nothing can possibly call your
mocks since the methods do not exist. To me this is like saying using
only reflection instead of calling methods directly is bettter because
you can run the code before it compiles. What am I missing, I don't
see that any value is lost with EasyMock and rMock in this case.

> As for EasyMock being more readable, EasyMock 1.x certainly wasn't. It
> looks like EasyMock 2.0 gives jMock a run for its money, at least in the
> easiest cases. The jury's out, since I haven't used it yet.

I think that is in the eyes of the beholder. Ironically I noticed that
a lot of people think that EasyMock is more intuitive than jMock and
hence more readable until someone explains to them why jMock is more
readable and then they change their mind. So which is better?

I think that EasyMock can allow for a bit too much messyness, that is
why I prefer rMock that is more strict and forces you to express
yourself in a certainway rather than providing you with all the
options all the time and leave it up to you to figure out how to use
them.

RMock also looks more like jMock when modifying method-calls which I
think is nice.

If i had to choose between jMock and EasyMock I'm not sure what I
would choose. Given that I used Java 1.5 it would probably be EasyMock
but I don't know. I have not yet found myself in a project that have
no requirements that some parts should run in earlier versions of
Java...

Throwing rMock into the picture I would pick it for at least the
following reasons (except that I am involved in developing it :) ):

* Strict workflow, all tests are forcecd to have the same structure.
* Sections for structuring and requering order of your tests.
* INTERCEPT! I have really started to love this feature, it is extremely useful.
* automatical verification, no way around it, you cannot forget
verifying your mocks even if you want to
* easy asserts for exceptions.
* Clear error messages, while I think EasyMock and JMock provide nice
errors rMocks are IMHO nicer, they give you more context to be able
to figure out what went wrong.
* assertThat out of the box (I think jMock has this feature aswell)
* Custom constraints and actions are easier to write, no StringBuffer
goo to describe your constraints
* References, among other thigs allows comparing arrays and describing
them in a readable way. no more [B@565238fa to String messages.
* DynamicTestSuites allows you to get better perfomance in your
nightly builds but removes the pain of keeping TestSuites in sync.

www.rmock.sf.net check it out!

Best Regards!
/Joakim Ohlrogge
